title: Alabama notes: Saban scoffs at NFL vs. college debate
text:
Alabama notes: Saban scoffs at NFL vs. college debate Alex Byington 3:20 a.m. CDT October 1, 2015 Alabama football coach Nick Saban gets angry with defensive back Tony Brown during Wednesday’s practice. (Photo: Vasha Hunt/AP) 3 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TUSCALOOSA — A longstanding debate among sports pundits re-emerged Wednesday with the sensational play of LSU sophomore running back Leonard Fournette . 
The argument involves the NFL’s three-year rule for allowing college players to enter the league, and whether transcendent players like Fournette — who are physically able to turn pro as sophomores — should sit out a year of college eligibility to avoid an injury that could potentially weaken their NFL stock. 
Alabama head coach Nick Saban , for one, isn’t buying any part of that argument. 
“I think college players develop while they’re here,” Saban said Wednesday on the weekly SEC football coaches teleconference. “I think you only get better by playing.” 
The argument stems from previous college standouts like former South Carolina defensive end Jadeveon Clowney and former Alabama receiver Amari Cooper , who dominated as underclassmen and were eventually top-five draft picks in recent years. 
Much like Saban, LSU head coach Les Miles doesn’t see any validity to the argument Fournette — whose 210.33 rushing yards per game leads the nation through three games — should put his own potential pro career ahead of what he’s got going on in college right now. 
“We just want Leonard to go to class, go to football, enjoy a smattering of media opportunities and play ball on Saturdays — have fun with his college,” Miles said on the teleconference. “I think the approach we have for him is a quality one.” 
Nevertheless, that hasn’t stopped NFL pundits from espousing the potential of college players taking their pro prospects into account when making the decision whether or not to risk injury playing college football. 
ProFootball.com’s Mike Florio suggested this week that Fournette, a true sophomore, should be the first college player to elect to sit out a season rather than assume the inherent risk of injury that comes with playing football, especially at a running back position where the shelf life is much shorter than others in the NFL. 
Once again, Saban scoffed at that reasoning. 
“And the notion that I guess you shouldn’t play because you might get injured — I don’t look at football as a dangerous game — (and) you can get injured playing any game, so that means you should never play?” Saban said. “You can actually get injured when you get onto the NFL. I think guys that worry about the wrong things rather than focusing on being a good teammate for their team, playing the best that they can play, (because) I think also those things always create more value for every individual player.” 
Case in point: Julio Jones , who recently signed a five-year, $71.25 million extension with the Atlanta Falcons, and has quickly emerged as one of the NFL’s top receivers through three games this season. 
“Julio was a very good player when he came here, he started as a freshman, but he got better and better and better every year that he was here,” Saban said. “And I think the bigger question is how did playing his junior year in college affect his pro career? He might be arguably the best receiver in the NFL, or one of them at least. So how did that negatively impact him?” 
After splashing onto the college scene with 924 receiving yards as a true freshman in 2008, and 596 receiving yards as a sophomore, Jones nearly doubled his previous season’s marks with 1,133 receiving yards on 78 catches and seven touchdowns as a junior, propelling him to the No. 6 overall pick in the 2011 NFL draft. 
Alabama’s native Georgians eager to play in Sanford: Dalvin Tomlinson grew up roughly 60 miles southwest of Athens, Georgia. 
The McDonough native had dreams of one day playing between the famed Sanford Stadium hedges. 
To say he bled Georgia red as a child wouldn’t be far off. 
But during his recruiting process, despite being “locked in on Georgia” early, the junior defensive tackle from Henry County (Georgia) elected to leave the state and signed with Alabama as part of a loaded 2012 class. 
Thankfully, Tomlinson and 13 of his Crimson Tide teammates will get their chance to play in front of their homestate fans when No. 13 Alabama (3-1, 0-1 SEC) travels to Athens on Saturday for a pivotal matchup with No. 8 Georgia. 
“Growing up, I always wanted to play in Sanford Stadium,” Tomlinson said Tuesday. “It’s always been a dream of mine. So it’s pretty exciting, getting ready to go back home and play at UGA for the first time.” 
Despite a pretty strict 24-hour rule, discussion about this weekend’s game began minutes after the Tide knocked off Louisiana-Monroe last Satuday, with senior safety Geno Matias-Smith (Atlanta) saying he and senior tailback Kenyan Drake (Powder Springs) were already talking about it in the locker room. 
“I was in the locker room talking with Drake about the Georgia game already, because we’re both Georgia guys,” Matias-Smith said Saturday. “We’ve already said that we’ve got to have a great week of practice and 100 percent focus on this, because it’s going to be big.” 
Those conversations have continued throughout the week. 
“We’ve just been talking about how excited we are for the game and the atmosphere,” Tomlinson said. “We remember going back to, like, recruiting days and going to the UGA games and how fun it used to be. So it’s going to be a fun game going back home and playing.” 3 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.mgmadv.com/1KNONcP TOP VIDEOS
